TEXT.citation: Early, R. J., & Whitehorn, J. (2003). One hundred Paiwan texts. Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University.
TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @book{100paiwantexts, author = {Robert Early and John Whitehorn}, title = {One Hundred Paiwan Texts}, year = {2003}, publisher = {Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University}}
TEXT.source: ti sa Qalamudis katua valałuvał (Tjakuvukuvuł village, p.204)

S.FORM: ka sitsuayan ti sa Qalamudis a Tsuluł navaik a qemałup.
ka sicoayan ti sa Qalamodis a Cololj navaik a qemaljop.
S.TRANSL: Once upon a time Qalamudis of the Tsuluł family had been hunting.

S.FORM: manu sekulił, sa kavalut a vuluq.
mano sekolilj, sa kavalot a voloq.
S.TRANSL: He tripped and lost hold of his spear,

S.FORM: manu malengleng a sema tjua vatsał.
mano malengleng a sema tjoa vacalj.
S.TRANSL: and it slid down into a deep pool.

S.FORM: qau inika kełang tu kudain nu malap.
qao inika keljang to kodain no malap.
S.TRANSL: He didn’t know what to do to get it back.

S.FORM: qau ledepen anga a vatsał i Dinualan.
qao ledepen anga a vacalj i Dinoalan.
S.TRANSL: So he dived into the pool at Dinualan.

S.FORM: manu lemdep; a i taladj izua qatjuvi a valałuvał.
mano lemdep; a i taladj izoa qatjovi a valaljovalj.
S.TRANSL: He dived in; and there in the pool was a monster snake.

S.FORM: "inu anga ku vuluq?" ayain ni sa Qalamudis.
"ino anga ko voloq?" ayain ni sa Qalamodis.
S.TRANSL: “Where is my spear?” Qalamudis said to it.

S.FORM: "izua ku siniparasudj tua tjułung; alapu," aya a valałuvał, qau alapen.
"izoa ko siniparasodj toa tjoljong; alapo," aya a valaljovalj, qao alapen.
S.TRANSL: “I lined it up there with the bamboo tube; take it,” said the monster. So he took it.

S.FORM: małavar tiamadju: "parepaqali-i; vava-i sa tja kinvava," aya a małavar.
maljavar tiamadjo: "parepaqali-i; vava-i sa tja kinvava," aya a maljavar.
S.TRANSL: They said to one another: “Let’s become friends. Let’s make beer and drink it,” they said to one another.

S.FORM: qau mirava ti sa Qalamudis, kemułup, kematsing, qemezetj tua pinułayłayan; sa vaik a łetaladj tua załum a kinvava.
qao mirava ti sa Qalamodis, kemoljop, kemacing, qemezetj toa pinoljayljayan; sa vaik a ljetaladj toa zaljom a kinvava.
S.TRANSL: Qalamudis got ready; he put on a sleeveless jacket and leggings, and pressed on his head an eagle-feather decoration; and he went into the water for a drinking party.

S.FORM: qau mapulaw anga ti sa Qalamudis; sema katsauan.
qao mapolaw anga ti sa Qalamodis; sema kacaoan.
S.TRANSL: Qalamudis got drunk. As he came out

S.FORM: "pangtjezu anga i tjanuaken nu tsuatsuay anga," ayain ni sa Qalamudis.
"pangtjezo anga i tjanoaken no coacoay anga," ayain ni sa Qalamodis.
S.TRANSL: he said: “After a time you come to my place,” he said to the monster.

S.FORM: qau mangtjez a valałuvał i tjai Tsuluł a kinvava.
qao mangtjez a valaljovalj i tjai Cololj a kinvava.
S.TRANSL: So the monster came to the Tsuluł house for a drinking party.

S.FORM: sa mapulaw anga azua valałuvał; vaik anga tsemikel.
sa mapolaw anga azoa valaljovalj; vaik anga cemikel.
S.TRANSL: The monster got drunk, and then went back.

S.FORM: maruquruqu i djalan, aya.
maroqoroqo i djalan, aya.
S.TRANSL: It rolled about in the path, they say.

S.FORM: sa azazua qali ni sa Qalamudis, nu kiqenetj a qaliqali, qatjuvi; łakua nu kiqenetj ti sa Qalamudis, tsautsau, aya a tjautsikel.
sa azazoa qali ni sa Qalamodis, no kiqenetj a qaliqali, qatjovi; ljakoa no kiqenetj ti sa Qalamodis, caocao, aya a tjaocikel.
S.TRANSL: Now that friend of Qalamudis, when others looked at it, it was a snake; but when Qalamudis looked at it, it was human, according to the story.
